snippet.textDisplay: Aside from styling, this thing seems utterly pointless. No seat can move like that and provide and actual supportive seat without massive amounts of small motors/ bladders which would make it way more expensive. The idea of a car expanding and shrinking as compared to an aeroplane? Ludicrous. Aeroplanes have to deal with more forces than a car by a level of magnitude. With a car you can simply bolt on another battery. There's multiple opportunities for this.  The one thing I wish they'd implement on cars is the suicide doors but it's pretty much a given that they're staying for high price cars and little else for the foreseeable. Why give plebs something fancy when cheaper stuff will do and you can put a price hike on the feature for richer customers cause it's rare?
snippet.textOriginal: Aside from styling, this thing seems utterly pointless. No seat can move like that and provide and actual supportive seat without massive amounts of small motors/ bladders which would make it way more expensive. The idea of a car expanding and shrinking as compared to an aeroplane? Ludicrous. Aeroplanes have to deal with more forces than a car by a level of magnitude. With a car you can simply bolt on another battery. There's multiple opportunities for this.  The one thing I wish they'd implement on cars is the suicide doors but it's pretty much a given that they're staying for high price cars and little else for the foreseeable. Why give plebs something fancy when cheaper stuff will do and you can put a price hike on the feature for richer customers cause it's rare?

snippet.textDisplay: This concept car is nothing but bullshit.  Those traditional car manufacturers do that to attract attention, nothing more.  They will not manufacture their concept cars because it's either not possible to mass produce, or too expensive or too complicated to manufacture, or there's not enough raw materials or parts available from the third party suppliers or maybe all of the above reasons.  But there's one company that actually build, mass produce and sell their actual "concept" vehicles.  And that is Tesla, the manufacturer of the best EV in the world.
snippet.textOriginal: This concept car is nothing but bullshit.  Those traditional car manufacturers do that to attract attention, nothing more.  They will not manufacture their concept cars because it's either not possible to mass produce, or too expensive or too complicated to manufacture, or there's not enough raw materials or parts available from the third party suppliers or maybe all of the above reasons.  But there's one company that actually build, mass produce and sell their actual "concept" vehicles.  And that is Tesla, the manufacturer of the best EV in the world.

Wow so many negative comments; yes it's a CONCEPT car guys. A good chance for the designers to be free thinking & come up with unusual/new ideas others may not have thought about...

I say It's always good to try and inspire people & stay positive to new ideas; Just think about all the things we wouldn't have if we didn't have new ideas!?! ...

snippet.textDisplay: I proposed an idea like this in 1989 in sci-fi-fi story I wrote, but for a police cruiser, that runs around 60-80% of the time as a 2 seater interceptor. Then if an arrest is made, a simple chassis lock would expand the rear with a fold out bench seat compartment for them. Anything is possible, not sure what the expandable front buys you here other than battery space? but that's assuming batteries will stay as large modules...
snippet.textOriginal: I proposed an idea like this in 1989 in sci-fi-fi story I wrote, but for a police cruiser, that runs around 60-80% of the time as a 2 seater interceptor. snippet.textDisplay:
For the record a plane with flaps retracted is efficient and streamlined. A plane with flaps extended is unaerodynamic but it doesn't care because extra lift is far more important for landing. Neither mode changes the contained, waterproof interior volume. This technology is not transferable to what this concept car needs.

A removable battery pack only makes sense if there's a shortage on cells, making them scarce and expensive. It does not make sense if you scale up cell production for the millions of cars we need annually and all the extra moving parts would add huge expense.

Did anybody try sitting in those chairs?
snippet.textOriginal:
For the record a plane with flaps retracted is efficient and streamlined.  A plane with flaps extended is unaerodynamic but it doesn't care because extra lift is far more important for landing.  Neither mode changes the contained, waterproof interior volume.  This technology is not transferable to what this concept car needs.

A removable battery pack only makes sense if there's a shortage on cells, making them scarce and expensive.  It does not make sense if you scale up cell production for the millions of cars we need annually and all the extra moving parts would add huge expense.

Did anybody try sitting in those chairs?

snippet.textDisplay: If another foot makes a difference in having more space in cities, we're in big trouble.  Airplanes have movable wings for engineering reasons, ....to provide sufficient lift when landing.  This thing stretches for marketing reasons.  All of the moving parts are costly and will break down.  Seems like a stupid gimmick, Renault is grasping at straws.  Give me something beautiful, efficient, and sporty, give me a Tesla.
snippet.textOriginal: If another foot makes a difference in having more space in cities, we're in big trouble.  Airplanes have movable wings for engineering reasons, ....to provide sufficient lift when landing.  This thing stretches for marketing reasons.  All of the moving parts are costly and will break down.  Seems like a stupid gimmick, Renault is grasping at straws.  Give me something beautiful, efficient, and sporty, give me a Tesla.

snippet.textDisplay: I often wonder why the battery packs weren't standardized on all electric cars. Instead of waiting for a charge at a station wouldn't it be better if you just swapped your drained battery pack for one that is charged? Have them all install from the bottom.. The charging stations could have several dozen charged battery packs in the queue. On the other hand perhaps charging will soon be as fast as the 5 minutes it might take to swap such a battery pack
snippet.textOriginal: I often wonder why the battery packs weren't standardized on all electric cars. Instead of waiting for a charge at a station wouldn't it be better if you just swapped your drained battery pack for one that is charged? Have them all install from the bottom.. I like the car, I like the styling, the interior needs work to get to market, but the whole battery swap malarkey was tried with the Renault Fluence ZE - and there's a reason you don't see any of those on the roads any more. I wish Renault would get this whole battery lease idea out of their heads and just build what appears to be a smashing looking concept.


ps, that french guy did talk a load of BS didn't he lol. Why say in 10 words what you can say in 200 eh? :)

snippet.textDisplay: The takeaway from this concept - for me, at least - is that not only is a smaller vehicle easier to get around a city with, but the smaller battery  in that configuration is much lighter, so you aren't wasting energy carrying a heavy pack which would just sap your range. To be able to turn your vehicle into a highway cruiser with a much larger battery is compelling. Probably not very affordable... but definitely a cool idea.
snippet.textOriginal: The takeaway from this concept - for me, at least - is that not only is a smaller vehicle easier to get around a city with, but the smaller battery  in that configuration is much lighter, so you aren't wasting energy carrying a heavy pack which would just sap your range. To be able to turn your vehicle into a highway cruiser with a much larger battery is compelling. Probably not very affordable... but definitely a cool idea.

snippet.textDisplay:
This presenter has got to develop the ability of telling someone their car is ridiculous and not fawn over everything electric.
You have to go to a dealer to get a big battery fitted before a longer trip ? No way.
Impact survivability ? Dubious.
Lots of sliding components in our climate ? Born to seize.
Huge wheels completely out of proportion with the car ? Embarrassing.
Seats that make you ache just looking at them. Impractical. And why would one turn round and face backwards. No one likes travelling in reverse.
Why the huge floor tunnel front and back ?
Renault should produce a saloon with 400+ miles range for £20K. That would be a concept we could all get over excited about.
RL we need the Wogan approach to the Eurovision Song Contest.
snippet.textOriginal:
This presenter has got to develop the ability of telling someone their car is ridiculous and not fawn over everything electric.
You have to go to a dealer to get a big battery fitted before a longer trip ? No way.
Impact survivability ? Dubious.
Lots of sliding components in our climate ? Born to seize.
Huge wheels completely out of proportion with the car ? Embarrassing.
Seats that make you ache just looking at them. Impractical. And why would one turn round and face backwards. No one likes travelling in reverse.
Why the huge floor tunnel front and back ?
Renault should produce a saloon with 400+ miles range for £20K. That would be a concept we could all get over excited about.
RL we need the Wogan approach to the Eurovision Song Contest.

snippet.textDisplay:
I keep saying it over and over. Lugging-around tons of batteries, hours spent charging, millions of dollars spent on charging infrastructure, billions spent on mining and manufacturing of batteries, makes no sense. WE SHOULD BE putting all this money and effort toward ELECTRIFYING THE ROAD. All these problems would go away, plus better environment, more efficient vehicles not hauling around batteries, no child cobalt mining...Not to mention super performance increases!!
Why not take advantage of a fuel that can travel along-side you?!! Can’t do that with petrol! UNLIMITED RANGE. “Range” argument is over!!
Think about it. Electrify HOV lanes to start. Don’t call them “HOV”...half the people using them are only single drivers anyway. Change them to “EV Lanes”. If you don’t have an EV, you shouldn’t be in that lane. That’s easier to enforce.
If you’d like this concept, just think of taking it even further....World Wide Grid. No more need for energy STORAGE. Just allow the rest of the to use energy where needed. If one side of the world is bright and sunny, and windmills are spinning, send the extra electricity to the dark side of the world. We already have the World Wide Web, why not the worldwide grid?
snippet.textOriginal:

All these problems would go away, plus better environment, more efficient vehicles not hauling around batteries, no child cobalt mining...Not to mention super performance increases!!
Why not take advantage of a fuel that can travel along-side you?!! Can’t do that with petrol! UNLIMITED RANGE. “Range” argument is over!!
Think about it. Electrify HOV lanes to start. Don’t call them “HOV”...half the people using them are only single drivers anyway. Change them to “EV Lanes”. If you don’t have an EV, you shouldn’t be in that lane. That’s easier to enforce. 
If you’d like this concept, just think of taking it even further....World Wide Grid. No more need for energy STORAGE. Just allow the rest of the to use energy where needed. If one side of the world is bright and sunny, and windmills are spinning, send the extra electricity to the dark side of the world. We already have the World Wide Web, why not the worldwide grid?

snippet.textDisplay:
Complex solutions rarely take hold in the practical realities of the marketplace. That said, concepts are important as a stimulus to all of us thinking beyond the possibilities we typically imagine. Designers and inventors feed the thoughts of other designers and inventors and what results is more than anyone originally envisioned. Engineers and designers love flights of imagination, else we would be bored with our jobs I suppose.
The business side of the equation than asks us hard questions which further modify our fantasies. I have no idea what it would cost to mass produce something like the Morphoz, but the obvious questions revolve around the cost of a basic city vehicle sitting in the garage alongside a long range capable vehicle. The comparison gets a bit more convoluted when I think about the differences between the aforementioned. Primary differences might be battery size followed by premium features. Do those two characteristics added to the basic vehicle cost outweigh the baseline cost of the city vehicle? I drive a 120 mile range, more urban style vehicle around town, and a Tesla for long range. The difference is mostly battery weight and the additional energy required to move that larger battery. Perhaps there is a logic there, but when I add in that all of my vehicles are powered by my own solar energy, and not the grid, does it matter that I drive around town in a small battery vehicle? Unlikely. Are long range vehicles going to become less frequently purchased? No way to predict that regardless of the strongly affirmative answer that some 'Tubers have. What I do know in the here and now is that anyone in the market for a new vehicle can likely afford a short range EV, and the good that they are doing by solving 80-90% of the problem is a giant first step.
snippet.textOriginal:
Complex solutions rarely take hold in the practical realities of the marketplace. That said, concepts are important as a stimulus to all of us thinking beyond the possibilities we typically imagine. Designers and inventors feed the thoughts of other designers and inventors and what results is more than anyone originally envisioned. Engineers and designers love flights of imagination, else we would be bored with our jobs I suppose. 
The business side of the equation than asks us hard questions which further modify our fantasies. I have no idea what it would cost to mass produce something like the Morphoz, but the obvious questions revolve around the cost of a basic city vehicle sitting in the garage alongside a long range capable vehicle. The comparison gets a bit more convoluted when I think about the differences between the aforementioned. Primary differences might be battery size followed by premium features. Do those two characteristics added to the basic vehicle cost outweigh the baseline cost of the city vehicle? I drive a 120 mile range, more urban style vehicle around town, and a Tesla for long range. The difference is mostly battery weight and the additional energy required to move that larger battery. Perhaps there is a logic there, but when I add in that all of my vehicles are powered by my own solar energy, and not the grid, does it matter that I drive around town in a small battery vehicle? Unlikely. Are long range vehicles going to become less frequently purchased? No way to predict that regardless of the strongly affirmative answer that some 'Tubers have. What I do know in the here and now is that anyone in the market for a new vehicle can likely afford a short range EV, and the good that they are doing by solving 80-90% of the problem is a giant first step.

snippet.textDisplay: A person living in a city may not need 500 miles of range BUT here in the good-ole USA I need a powerful pickup truck that I can pull a 10,000 pound trailer up and down hills that has a 500 mile range ( or more if possible).  I may have to drive 150 miles one way, then drive another 20 to 30 miles around the work area, then 150 miles back home.  Not to mention longer road trips on interstate highways of 500 to 700 miles at a time.  In the US we need an electric vehicle capable of long distance driving.  I mean, just look at the long expanse of open roads we have.   I don't need a big rig but the farmers, ranchers and the every day working man needs a real working man's truck.  I really want an electric vehicle to get away from the expense and upkeep of the old gas burning GMC 2500 that I have but the range and pulling power is still an issue for me from a pickup truck standpoint.  As far as a family car is concerned a 300 to 500 mile range might work but still for long trips 500 to 700 miles would be great.
snippet.textOriginal: A person living in a city may not need 500 miles of range BUT here in the good-ole USA I need a powerful pickup truck that I can pull a 10,000 pound trailer up and down hills that has a 500 mile range ( or more if possible).  I may have to drive 150 miles one way, then drive another 20 to 30 miles around the work area, then 150 miles back home.  Not to mention longer road trips on interstate highways of 500 to 700 miles at a time.  In the US we need an electric vehicle capable of long distance driving.  I mean, just look at the long expanse of open roads we have.   I don't need a big rig but the farmers, ranchers and the every day working man needs a real working man's truck.  I really want an electric vehicle to get away from the expense and upkeep of the old gas burning GMC 2500 that I have but the range and pulling power is still an issue for me from a pickup truck standpoint.  As far as a family car is concerned a 300 to 500 mile range might work but still for long trips 500 to 700 miles would be great.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm much less euphoric about this idea, because I believe that this is not the right solution for the problem. If you really want to minimise road footprint you need to put more people in minivan sized people mover type vehicles, not build slightly smaller cars. For you travelling and vacationing needs, it would make more sense to just rent a suitable vehicle for that specific time, when you need it. Ideally you wouldn't even own a car, because quite frankly, parked cars in cities are the worst way of utilising space that otherwise could be used for so many better things. Think communal spaces, where people could meet and socialise, communicate, enjoy life. I think that autonomous vehicles as shared ride services with intelligent on-demand routing would be the perfect solution.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm much less euphoric about this idea, because I believe that this is not the right solution for the problem. If you really want to minimise road footprint you need to put more people in minivan sized people mover type vehicles, not build slightly smaller cars. For you travelling and vacationing needs, it would make more sense to just rent a suitable vehicle for that specific time, when you need it. Ideally you wouldn't even own a car, because quite frankly, parked cars in cities are the worst way of utilising space that otherwise could be used for so many better things. Think communal spaces, where people could meet and socialise, communicate, enjoy life. I think that autonomous vehicles as shared ride services with intelligent on-demand routing would be the perfect solution.

snippet.textDisplay: This car would be a god send for me (in an ideal world). I live in rural scotland with my wife and in-laws. Rob you're quite right, 70-90% I don't need more than 100 miles range. Having  300miles in your back pocket is a great peace of mind.

snippet.textDisplay: That is quite funky - some nice ideas, including the seats. But what I really want Renault to do is sell me an electric Master that doesn't cost 30 grand (!) more than the diesel Master (56K vs 26K). Same battery as the Kangoo which is only 7.5K extra for the electric model. For 30 grand we should get a battery a hell of a lot bigger than 33kWh! If it was 120kWh I'd give 'em 56 grand next month and make a serious electric camper. But it's not. I have no idea why Renault think this pricing makes sense.

snippet.textDisplay: FIAT launched the Centoventi concept car last year with the idea of expandable battery packs. Check it out on youtube. Be good if someone launched a concept for a powerpack that would bolt into all the existing cars which we need to recycle into new electric ones before developing new massive SUV type concepts.
